EL Banco Comunal San Pedro De Pueblo se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Pueblo Nuevo del Cantón Santa Ana, lugar de gente honesta y dedicada a las faenas del campo y a la ganadería, con bellos paisajes campestres y gente amable.

En este lugar vive la señora Lucila, tiene 50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos los mismos que ya son mayores de edad, uno de ellos aún vive con ella. Su esposo es agricultor.

Doña Lucila es una muy buena madre y esposa que se dedica al comercio, vende ropa interior por catálogos y productos de Avon y Yanbal  (perfumes, cremas, bisutería entre otras cosas), su forma de venta es puerta a puerta ya que sale tres días a la semana  a enseñar su revista y hacer los pedidos los mismos que luego entrega a crédito y cobra cada ocho días, ella lleva más de 15 años en este negocio y le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar ropa interior, cremas, perfumes y cosméticos. Lleva 7 ciclos en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y sin tantos requisitos.
 
Su sueño es seguir en su negocio ya que le encanta lo que hace.
texts.en:
The communal bank "San Pedro De Pueblo" meets every fifteen days in the Pueblo Nuevo del Cantón Santa Ana parish area, a place with honest people who are dedicated to work in the countryside and to livestock.  It has beautiful country landscapes and kind people.

Lucila lives in this place.  She is fifty years old, is married, and through this relationship, she has three children who are of age.  One of her children still lives with her.  Her husband is a farmer.

Lucila is a very good mother and wife and makes a living in trade.  She sells undergarments through catalogs, as well as Avon and Yanbal products (perfumes, creams, imitation jewelry, and other items).  Her form of selling is going door-to-door.  Three days a week, she shows her magazine to clients and fills orders that are later paid by credit.  She collects payments every eight days.  She has been in this business for more than fifteen years and it is going very well.  

This loan is to buy undergarments, creams, perfumes, and cosmetics.  She has taken seven loans through this communal bank and likes it because the loans are quick and do not have many requirements.

Her dream is to continue with her business, since she loves what she does.

loans.use: to buy undergarments, creams, perfumes, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas, a mother of eight children, is 53 years old. She resides in the Bovel district of Battambang Province, Cambodia. Meas still has one child to take care of who is still in school. 

Meas makes a living via rice cultivation and planting oranges, which she has been involved with for 15 years. The current business earns her about 30,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

This is the third loan cycle for Meas with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. She has used the past loans, which she has fully paid back with success, to keep up the good progress of her business as well as her living conditions. 

Now Meas is applying for a loan of 4,000,000 KHR to buy a tractor to help her in the rice field. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yield, so as to make a better living and keep her child in school.

loans.use: to buy a tractor to help her in the rice field.

loans.name: Abtehal Group

texts.en:
This group is called Abtehal Group which consists of four women who live in Aden, Yemen. They applied for a combined loan of YER 140,000 from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank (AMB) to support different type of businesses. 

Basma works hard to offer a good life for her family. She is a 27-year-old, married woman and has two children who live in Aden. She is the bread-winner who has sold mobile recharge cards, door-to-door, for four years. 

Basma would like to improve her business, so she applied for a loan of YER 50,000 from AMB to buy more mobile recharge cards for sale, to get more profit. She hopes to enroll her children in private school.

loans.use: to buy more mobile recharge cards for sale.

loans.name: Suvd-Erdene

texts.en:
Mrs. Suvd-erdene, 30 years old, lives with her husband and four children in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. She has been running a business selling hand watering carts at an outdoor market. Her husband, a welder, makes the hand carts his wife sells. Usually people living in the ger district area, which has no water supply system, purchase these hand carts to transport water barrels.

Suvd-erdene's family lives in a traditional Mongolian ger (portable felt dwelling) and just began building their house. But due to a lack of finance, the house is not completed. She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase large amounts of iron and rubber. As a result, she can generate more income, which will be used to finish the house. The completed house will definitely provide the family with comfort and warmth.

loans.use: to purchase large amounts of rubber and iron

loans.name: Adel

texts.en: Adel is a 42-year-old married man. He has four children who all live all in Sana`a, Yemen. His children are studying in school. He dreams to see his children grow up well. Adel is a teacher who is described as a kindly man for his students. He intends to buy home appliances for his house, but the amount he has is not enough to buy what he needs. So he has applied for a loan of 300,000 YER from AMB to buy a fridge, washing machine and television, etc. Adel dreams of studying for a master's in his specialization and improve his living standards.

loans.use: to buy a fridge, washing machine and television, etc.

loans.name: Voert's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural village in the Ek Phnom district of Cambodia, Voert is 37 years old and married, with three children, all of whom are still in school. The family’s main sources of income come from Voert's and her husband's wages as laborers for others in their village. They supplement the income by catching fish. Engaging in this business for several years, Voert can earn about KHR 30,000 per day to meet her family’s needs.

Voert has been with VisionFund Cambodia for three cycles and completely paid back the past loans. The other member of Voert's Group has been with VisionFund Cambodia for two cycles. 

Now, Voert is leading her group of two to ask for a new loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy a boat for her fish-catching business. She hopes to catch more fish and sell them for a good price, to make a better living and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy a boat for her fish-catching business.

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en:
Mom, 43 years old, is a villager residing in a rural area of Battambang province’s Ek Phnom district, Cambodia. She is married and has six children, three of whom are school-aged children. To support the family, Mom works weaving mats, while her husband works as a construction worker to earn additional income. Mom and her husband have been doing this work for 20 years, earning about 32,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs.
 
Mom has been with VisionFund for six loan cycles, and she completely paid back the past loans. She has successfully used the past loans to better support her family. Now she is forming a group of three, to ask for a new loan. Mom, who is the leader, will use her portion of the new loan to buy construction materials for her husband’s business. She hopes to realize more income from his current business, so as to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her husband’s business
